questions.text: 1. A 45 year old male with chronic malnutrition is being treated with Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN). 24 hours after the initiation of TPN, he develops hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia. Which of the following best describes the reason for this?

choices.text: Insulin causes the influx of K+, Mg²⁺, PO₄³⁻ into the cell

questions.solution:
The electrolyte abnormalities in the context of total parenteral nutrition are indicative of refeeding syndrome which is best described by insulin causing the influx of K+, Mg²⁺, PO₄³⁻ into the cell.

Refeeding syndrome is a metabolic complication that can occur in patients who are severely malnourished and are rapidly reintroduced to nutrition. This occurs due to increased insulin secretion from acute carbohydrate introduction.

This is due to a shift from catabolism to anabolism, which leads to a number of metabolic changes. One of these changes is increased insulin secretion. This increase in insulin promotes glycogenesis, protein synthesis and also activates the sodium-potassium ATPase symporter, leading to movement of potassium into the cells Magnesium and phosphate are also taken up similarly, which can lead to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia. Additionally, insulin can inhibit the kidneys' ability to reabsorb phosphate, which can lead to hypophosphatemia - the hallmark of refeeding syndrome. Hyperglycemia is seen due to the acutely increased body insulin production not being able to keep up with the rapidly increasing blood sugar levels. 

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to: Starvation, Alcoholism, Delayed nutritional support, Anorexia nervosa, Massive weight loss in obese patients

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention of refeeding involves correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalance, administering thiamine and increasing calorie intake gradually.

Options A, B and C: The other answer choices are incorrect because they do not explain the metabolic changes that lead to refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: 2. In most cases of endemic and familial multinodular goitre, excess iodine intake can cause signs of thyrotoxicosis. What is this effect known as?
questions.solution:
This effect is known as Jod–Basedow effect which is characterized by iodine induced hyperthyroidism.

In patients with goitre, excessive thyroid hormone synthesis can be caused by increased iodine exposure either as a dietary supplement or as contrast medium, resulting in signs of thyrotoxicosis. It is due to overactivation of the thyroid gland or autonomous nodules within the gland after iodine repletion without adequate feedback control from the pituitary gland. This phenomenon do not occur in individuals with normal thyroid gland. The Jod-Basedow effect is named after "jod", the German word for iodine, and Carl Adolph von Basedow, the German physician who first described the effect.

Other options: 

Option A:  Wolff–Chaikoff effect is iodine-induced suppression of the thyroid gland. In individuals with a normal thyroid, excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification and thyroid hormone production. However, in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease, the suppressive action of high iodide may persist. Clinical relevance: The Wolff–Chaikoff effect has been used as a treatment principle against thyroid storm by infusion of a large amount of iodine to suppress the thyroid gland.

Option C: Pemberton phenomenon refers to the appearance of neck vein distention and difficulty breathing when a person with a large retrosternal goiter raises their arms, due to compression caused by the mass in that position.

Option D: Grave's effect typically refers to the systemic effects caused by Graves' disease, which is an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: 3. What is the most common type of pituitary adenoma?
questions.solution:
The most common type of pituitary adenoma is a non-functioning adenoma. 

Approximately one-third of all adenomas are clinically non-functioning and produce no distinct clinical hypersecretory syndrome. Most of them arise from gonadotrope cells and may secrete small amounts of α- and β-glycoprotein hormone subunits or, rarely, intact circulating gonadotropins.

questions.text:
4. Complete clinical cure for malaria can be achieved by?

1. Artemesin 2. Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine 3. Chloroquine 4. Primaquine
questions.solution:
Complete clinical cure for malaria can be achieved by Artemisin, Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine and Chloroquine.

Artemisin is used for the treatment of severe P. falciparum malaria and is also effective against the asexual erythrocytic stages of P. vivax. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are used in which the rapid-acting and rapidly eliminated artemisinin component is paired with a slower-acting and slower-eliminated partner drug with a distinct antiparasitic mechanism of action. Such an approach is required because artemisinins, when administered alone, require more than 7 days of therapy to eliminate parasites, but when paired with an effective partner, the duration of treatment gets reduced.

Chloroquine is highly effective against the erythrocytic forms of P. vivax, P. ovale, P. malariae, P. knowlesi, and chloroquine-sensitive strains of P. falciparum. Chloroquine rapidly controls the clinical symptoms and parasitemia of acute malaria. Most patients become completely afebrile within 24 to 48 hours after receiving therapeutic doses. Sulfadoxine is a slow-acting blood schizonticide and is more active against P. falciparum than P. vivax.

Primaquine, in contrast to other antimalarials, acts on exoerythrocytic tissue stages of Plasmodium spp. in the liver to prevent and cure relapsing malaria. Primaquine is primarily used for terminal chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale (relapsing) infections due to its high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of these Plasmodium species. It also has gametocytocidal activity against P. falciparum and other Plasmodium species. However, primaquine is inactive against asexual blood-stage parasites, rendering it unsuitable as the principal treatment for an acute episode of malaria.

questions.text: 5. A 30-year-old man presents with severe headache and vomiting. There is neck stiffness, photophobia and Brudzinski's sign is positive. CT head shows a small hydrocephalus but no haemorrhage. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a severe headache, vomiting, neck stiffness, photophobia and positive Brudzinski's sign, with CT head showing a small hydrocephalus but no haemorrhage, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Subarachnoid Haemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Other options:

Option A and B: Bacterial Meningitis is characterised by high fever, neck stiffness, and positive Brudzinski's sign. Viral encephalitis is characterised by a throbbing headache. Delayed neurologic deficits like small hydrocephalus and absence of fever are more associated with SAH rather than Bacterial meningitis and Viral encephalitis.  

Option D: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus leads to urinary incontinence, cognitive decline, and difficulty in walking.

Pearl PM0111: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

* Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)

* Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone

* Lens or lentiform shaped opacity

* Presence of a characteristic lucid interval

* Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH



 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

* Source: Venous - bridging veins

* Cause: Trauma

* Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)

* Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache

* CT findings: Crescent opacity

* Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage



 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

* Source: Venous - bridging veins

* Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants

* Crescent clots

* Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls



 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

* Source: Arterial

* Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)

* M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery

* Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache

* CSF: Xanthochromia

* Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space

* Treatment: Early repair by clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm. Nimodipine and IV fluids with monitoring to prevent vasospasm.



 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

* Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage

* Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)

* Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma

* Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)

* Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: 6. The CT scan of a 26-year-old who presented with complaints of diarrhoea for 6 months is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with chronic diarrhoea and CT showing ahaustral colon (black arrows) with engorgement of mesenteric vessels (white arrows) points towards the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that usually involves the rectum and extends proximally to involve all or part of the colon, leading to pancolitis. Loss of haustrations in the colon occurs in severe disease. Clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhoea (often with blood), rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus.

In mild inflammation, the mucosa is erythematous with a fine granular surface that resembles sandpaper, while in severe disease, the mucosa is haemorrhagic, edematous, ulcerated and can also lead to pseudopolyps as a result of epithelial regeneration in longstanding disease.

On barium studies, the lead pipe appearance refers to the complete loss of haustral markings in the affected section of the colon, which appears smooth-walled and cylindrical, resulting from chronic inflammation.

CT/MRI features of ulcerative colitis include:

* Loss of haustrations

* Lead-pipe colon appearance

* Bowel wall thickening

* Mucosal hyperenhancement

* Luminal narrowing

* Pericolonic fat stranding

* Pseudopolyps

* Mesenteric vessel engorgement

Other options:

Option B: The terminal ileum is dilated with a patulous ileocaecal valve and a contracted caecum is seen on CECT in tuberculous colitis. Ascites, peritoneal involvement, and lymphadenopathy can also be seen. Central caseous necrosis in lymph nodes appears hypoechoic on ultrasound and shows peripheral enhancement on CT or MRI.

Option C: Crohn's disease shows discrete ulcers with skip lesions, giving a cobblestone appearance. The ileocaecal valve is affected and can be enlarged.

Option D: Pseudomembrane colitis imaging shows a grossly thickened wall, which shows marked mucosal enhancement and is hypodense in the submucosa due to oedema. This produces a target sign, which is described as the ‘accordion sign’.

questions.text: 7. A 25-year-old presents with recurrent urinary stones and a pathological fracture. Blood reports show high calcium and PTH. Which of the following tests is preferred for localising the parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
Sestamibi scan is preferred for localising the parathyroid gland.

Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation. It shows passive diffusion across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria. Because of its accumulation in the mitochondria, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending on the number of mitochondria in each tissue. 

In parathyroid adenomas, there is a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content.

The three protocols for Sestamibi scanning:

* Single-isotope dual-phase scan

* Dual-isotope subtraction imaging

* Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)

SPECT is commonly used because of its improved spatial resolution. Sestamibi combined with CT can be used to detect smaller parathyroid tissues. It can also detect ectopic glands in the mediastinum or the deeper cervical region.

The image below shows a Sestamibi scan.



Other options:

Option A: Ultrasonography is inexpensive and noninvasive. It can miss adenomas located in retro-oesophageal, retrosternal or retrotracheal areas. It can also be difficult to differentiate between a small parathyroid gland and a normal-appearing lymph node.

Option B: FDG-PET CT is expensive and is not widely available.

Option C: FNAC of the parathyroid alone is not enough to accurately localise the parathyroid glands.

questions.text: 8. A resident ordered the medical student to take procalcitonin for a patient with suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia and was on empirical antibiotic therapy. What is the role of procalcitonin?
questions.solution:
Procalcitonin role is to decide the duration of antibiotics.

Procalcitonin assays are used to decide the duration of antibiotics and for initiating or discontinuing antibiotics in lower respiratory tract infections and for patients with sepsis. 

C-reactive protein (CRP) and Procalcitonin (PCT) are common markers of inflammation that increase in response to  infections. However, PCT is not accurate enough to diagnose community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and should not be the  basis for withholding initial antibiotic treatment.  These tests should be used alongside patient history, physical examination, imaging studies, and other lab tests to ensure effective management and antibiotic stewardship for seriously ill CAP patients.

questions.text: 9. A 70-year-old lady with Parkinsonism suffers from aspiration pneumonia, with 3 episodes for the past 6 months. X Ray shows bibasilar bronchiectasis. Moderate oropharyngeal dysphagia is present, and had a poor cough reflex. What is the best appropriate step for long-term prevention of recurrent aspiration pneumonia?

choices.text: Nebulization with N-acetyl cysteine to reduce secretions
Azithromycin for antibacterial prophylaxis and prokinetic effect.

questions.solution:
PEG gastrostomy tube insertion is the best appropriate step for long-term prevention of recurrent aspiration pneumonia.

Chronic neurological disorders, such as Parkinson’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, can present with oropharyngeal dysphagia. For nutritional support, feeding through a nasogastric tube may be considered. However, it do not protect against the aspiration of saliva or refluxed gastric contents. So, Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) is a commonly used method for insertion of a gastrostomy tube in patients with swallowing disorders. It helps in the prevention of aspiration in patients with recurrent pneumonia. 

A PEG tube does not irritate the nasal mucosa. The tube is less likely to become displaced, and hence the feed can be given more reliably. It takes approximately 10 days for a fibrous tract to form around the PEG tube, and if the PEG is displaced or removed during that time, there is a high risk of peritonitis.

Other options:

Option A: High-frequency chest wall oscillation involves an inflatable vest that is attached to a machine. The machine mechanically performs chest physical therapy by vibrating at a high frequency. The vest vibrates the chest to loosen and thin mucus.

questions.text: 10. Which of the following is not a risk factor for recurrent nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Hypercitraturia is not a risk factor for recurrent nephrolithiasis.

Urine citrate is a natural inhibitor of calcium-containing stones, and hence, lower urine citrate excretion increases the risk of stone formation. Citrate reabsorption is determined by the intracellular pH of proximal tubular cells. Citrate excretion gets reduced in metabolic acidosis due to an increase in the reabsorption of filtered citrate.

Hypercalciuria increases the formation of calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones, and hyperoxaluria increases the formation of calcium oxalate stones. Hyperuricosuria is a risk factor for uric acid stone formation, which is found in individuals with excess purine consumption and rare genetic conditions that lead to overproduction of uric acid.

Higher dietary calcium intake is related to a lower risk of stone formation. This may be due to a reduction in intestinal absorption of dietary oxalate, resulting in lower oxalate levels in the urine. Low calcium intake is contraindicated as it increases the risk of stone formation. Supplemental calcium may increase the risk of stone formation. Higher intake of animal protein leads to increased excretion of calcium and uric acid, as well as decreased urinary excretion of citrate, resulting in increased risk of stone formation.

Many potassium-rich foods increase urinary citrate excretion due to their alkali content. Dietary factors such as magnesium and phytate have been inconsistently associated with lower stone risk.

questions.text:
11. Which of the statements is true about lumbar puncture?

1. LP is urgently indicated if the CT scan is negative in suspected SAH 2. Post-dural puncture headache is common in females and older adults 3. Meningitis after LP is an unusual side effect 4. LP is safely done in thrombocytopenia more than 10000
questions.solution:
Lumbar puncture (LP) is urgently indicated if the CT scan is negative in suspected SAH, and meningitis after LP is an unusual side effect are the correct statements.

Statement 1: LP is urgently indicated if the CT scan is negative in suspected SAH. It helps to establish the presence of subarachnoid blood. Lysis of the red blood cells and subsequent conversion of haemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 hours. This xanthochromic spinal fluid peaks in intensity at 48 hours and lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.

Statement 3: Meningitis after LP is an unusual side effect, as all aseptic precautions are taken while performing it. Meningitis presents with symptoms such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and often a rash, indicating a possible bacterial cause. When evaluating such patients, it is crucial to perform a lumbar puncture to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Other statements:

Statement 2: Post-dural puncture headache is common in young females. It is generally due to continued epidural leakage of CSF from the dural puncture site.

Statement 4: LP is safely done in thrombocytopenia, more than 10000 is incorrect. Performing a lumbar puncture in patients with thrombocytopenia increases the risk of bleeding. Lumber puncture should be done in patients with an adequate platelet count (>20 x 109/L) and without clinical haemorrhages.

Pearl PM0446: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

* May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).

* Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.

* Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.

* Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.

* Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

* Supine position

* IV fluids

* Caffeine and analgesia

* Epidural blood patch

questions.text: 12. A young female presents with Septic shock. She has been treated with 30ml/kg crystalloids IV Fluids, however, her MAP stays at 56. Which of the following would be the next best step in management for her?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine is recommended as the first-choice vasopressor in the management of hypotension in a patient with septic shock, and will be the next best step in management. 

Sepsis is defined as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection and is diagnosed by the presence of infection with an increase of 2 or more points according to the SOFA score. Septic shock is diagnosed when a patient has sepsis, along with the requirement of a vasopressor to maintain mean arterial pressure at 65 mm Hg and serum lactate > 2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation.

Management of sepsis includes:

* Early initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics and cardiorespiratory resuscitation to prevent further organ failure due to infection and hypoperfusion

* A blood sample should be sent for cultures before antibiotics are initiated, but empirical antibiotic therapy should be started within the first hour

* Aggressive administration of intravenous fluids should begin within the first three hours, and crystalloids are given at 30 mL/kg

* Norepinephrine is the recommended first-choice vasopressor, and the target mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 65 mmHg, which should ideally be monitored by an arterial catheter

* Sepsis-associated ARDS should be managed by mechanical ventilation with a target tidal volume of 6 ml/kg with high PEEP

* Other general considerations include prophylaxis against thromboembolism unless contraindicated, stress ulcer prevention using antacids, blood glucose management, and renal replacement therapy in case of AKI

Other Options:

Option A: Vasopressin is used only to reduce the norepinephrine dose.

Option C: Dopamine should only be used in specific situations, such as in patients with a risk of tachyarrhythmia or relative bradycardia.

Option D: Corticosteroids 200mg STAT is not the initial choice to manage the patient.

Pearl PM1636: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

* Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count

* Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation

* Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)

* Hepatic function - Bilirubin

* Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

* Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg

* Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min

* Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

* SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.

* qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

* Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 OR

* Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text:
13. A 70-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with worsening shortness of breath, pedal oedema, and cough. The ECHO shows concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, left atrial dilation, EF - 60%, normal systolic function, and grade 2 diastolic dysfunction. BNP is 920. What would be the best long-term management for this patient?

SGLT2i - Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter-2 inhibitors

HFpEF- Heart failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction

EF- Ejection Fraction

BNP - Brain Natriuretic Peptide

choices.text: Ivabradine to decrease heart rate and improve ventricular filling
Coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy
Initiate SGLT2i and loop diuretics for management of HFpEF

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with EF-60 % suggests Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF). The best long-term management for this patient will be to initiate SGLT2i and loop diuretics for management of HFpEF. 

Treatment of diabetic patients with SGLT2i has been shown to reduce the incidence of heart failure, raising the possibility that these agents may be effective in such patients. This is a novel therapy for HFpEF, and trials are still going on to assess the benefits. Angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors (ARNI) are also a part of novel therapy under trials. Treatment of HFpEF focuses on decongestion, aggressive management of medical comorbidities, and relief of exacerbating factors.

Other options:

Option A: Ivabradine, an inhibitor of the If current in the sinoatrial node, selectively reduces heart rate without affecting cardiac contractility or vascular tone in cases of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

Option B: Coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy is done in cases of suspected coronary artery blockage, such as when a patient presents with angina.

Option D: Digoxin is used to improve myocardial contractility in HFrEF. It exerts a mild inotropic effect, attenuates carotid sinus baroreceptor activity, and is sympatho-inhibitory. These effects decrease serum norepinephrine levels, plasma renin levels, and possibly aldosterone levels.

questions.text: 14. A 36-year-old male with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presented with cervical pain and myelopathy. Which of the following is the most probable cause?

choices.text: Compression fracture of cervical vertebral body
Degeneration of cervical spine facets due to Osteoarthritis

questions.solution:
Atlanto-axial subluxation is the most probable cause in this patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, presenting with cervical pain and myelopathy.

Atlantoaxial involvement of the cervical spine can lead to compressive myelopathy and neurologic dysfunction. Neurological manifestations are rarely a presenting sign or symptom of atlantoaxial disease, but they may evolve with progressive instability of C1 on C2. The prevalence of atlantoaxial subluxation has been declining in recent years and occurs now in a lesser number of patients.  Rheumatoid arthritis rarely affects the thoracic and lumbar spine.

In the initial stages of rheumatoid arthritis, the small joints of the hands and the feet are most frequently involved. These most frequently include the wrist, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) in the upper limb, and metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints in the lower limb. Note that distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) involvement is not seen in RA and usually represents coexistent osteoarthritis.

The patients complain of early morning joint stiffness lasting for more than an hour, which improves with activity. As the disease progresses, the following deformities may be seen:

* Trigger finger occurs due to tenosynovitis of the flexor tendons

* Ulnar deviation of the hand occurs due to MCP joint subluxation

* Swan-neck deformity occurs due to hyperextension of the PIP and flexion of the DIP

* Boutonnière deformity occurs due to flexion of the PIP and the hyperextension of the DIP

questions.text: 15. Which of the following is not seen in cardiac failure?

choices.text: Shortness of breath within 2-3 hours after going to bed

questions.solution:
Non-pulsatile elevated JVP is not seen in cardiac failure.

Non-pulsatile elevated JVP is seen in cardiac tamponade. Tamponade results in elevated right atrial pressure and elevated right ventricular pressures. This results in a prominent x descent and a diminished or absent y descent in the JVP. The resultant JVP is elevated but nonpulsatile in nature due to the persistently raised pressures in the right side of the heart. 

Orthopnea, right hypochondriac region pain, and shortness of breath within 2-3 hours after going to bed are seen in cardiac failure.

Cardiac failure is a complex clinical syndrome that results from any structural or functional impairment of ventricular filling or ejection of blood, leading to cardinal manifestations of dyspnea, fatigue, and fluid retention.

Orthopnea refers to dyspnea that occurs in the recumbent position within 1–2 minutes of lying down. It occurs due to the redistribution of fluid from the abdomen and lower body into the chest, increased work of breathing due to decreased lung compliance and elevation of the diaphragm in patients with ascites or hepatomegaly. The symptoms may be relieved by raising the head and chest with pillows or an adjustable bed.

Right hypochondriac region pain occurs due to stretching of the hepatic capsule resulting from hepatic congestion in right heart failure.

Shortness of breath within 2-3 hours after going to bed is known as Paroxysmal Nocturnal Dyspnea. It refers to episodes of shortness of breath that awaken a patient from sleep with feelings of anxiety and suffocation. The symptoms get relieved on sitting upright for 30 minutes or more.

Right heart failure Left heart failure
Due to congestion in the systemic circulation Due to congestion in the pulmonary circulation

Symptoms and signs:

  • Right hypochondriac region pain
  • Congestive hepatomegaly
  • Positive hepatojugular reflux
  • Ascites
  • Bilateral pitting oedema 
  • Weight gain due to oedema
  • Fatigue- due to ↓pumping of blood to the lungs, leading to ↓oxygenation of the blood

 

Symptoms and signs: 

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (characteristic of LVF)
  • Pulmonary rales 
  • Increased PCWP
  • Fatigue- due to ↓cardiac output

 

 

 


Pearl PM0288: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality

Cause

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Pulmonary congestion

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.)

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: 16. What is the earliest manifestation of Multiple Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Sensory loss is the earliest manifestation of Multiple Sclerosis. 

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. The common symptoms of multiple sclerosis are as follows:

* Sensory symptoms - paresthesia (tingling sensations, pins and needles sensation), hypesthesia (numbness)

* Optic neuritis - decreased visual acuity and colour perception, unilateral/ bilateral, visual blurring

* Limb weakness - spastic paralysis, gait disturbances, Babinski's sign positive

* Facial weakness

* Vertigo

* Ataxia

* Hearing loss 

* Bladder dysfunction

* Lhermitte's sign (shooting pain down the back on neck movement)

* Uhthoff's sign (worsening of neurological symptoms on exposure to elevated temperatures, eg, hot shower)

MRI is the imaging modality of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity. It shows finger-like periventricular and callosal lesions, perpendicular to the ventricular surface (Dawson fingers).

questions.text: 17. What is the most common presentation of SLE?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is arthralgia/myalgia.

Other common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:

* Skin- photosensitivity

* Kidneys- proteinuria

* Neurologic- cognitive impairment, psychosis, depression, and seizures

* Cardiac- pericarditis

* Pulmonary- pleuritis

* Hematologic- anaemia

questions.text: 18. A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of increased chronic urinary frequency for the past 3 months. On examination, the prostate is normal and supra pubic tenderness is seen. Urine analysis shows a leukocyte count ( 50/ Ul), and culture shows no bacterial growth. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of increased chronic urinary frequency for the last 3 months, normal prostate, suprapubic tenderness, with urine analysis showing a leukocyte count (> 50/ Ul), and culture showing no bacterial growth suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Sterile pyuria.

Sterile pyuria is pyuria in the absence of bacteriuria and indicates an inflammatory response that may still be related to urinary tract infection or that may be a response to another pathology, such as fastidious organisms (e.g. TB, gonorrhoea), carcinoma in situ (CIS), bladder stones or other inflammatory conditions. Suprapubic tenderness can be seen in patients with cystitis and elderly patients with urinary incontinence or overactive bladder.

Other options:

Option A and C: Since the prostate is normal, the diagnosis cannot be Chronic bacterial prostatitis or Granulomatous prostatitis. Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents with a soft, boggy and tender prostate.

Option D: Acute urinary infection will lead to bacterial growth on culture.

questions.text: 19. A 46-year-old man with a history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus presents with a complicated UTI, urinalysis shows more than 40 WBCs. He is hypotensive and not responding to IV fluids. What would be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
A diabetic patient with a complicated UTI, now presenting with hypotension unresponsive to IV fluids, is suggestive of urosepsis (septic shock). Hence, the patient should be treated with Meropenem. In septic shock, there is peripheral vasodilation due to toxins from the infectious agent causing endothelial injury and fluid leak, leading to hypotension, which can be refractory to fluid therapy in the early stages.

Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are more common in diabetic patients due to poor metabolic control, altered immune status, poor bladder control and incomplete voiding. E. coli is the most common organism to cause urinary tract infections. Other organisms causing infections include Klebsiella spp, Proteus spp, Enterobacter spp and Enterococci. A complicated urinary tract infection is accompanied by symptoms that suggest the infection extends beyond the bladder, such as a fever or signs and symptoms of systemic illness.

ESBL-positive E. coli is an emerging pathogen responsible for urinary tract infections. Oral antibiotic therapy may not consistently be effective against this organism. For complicated infections caused by ESBL-positive E. coli, it is recommended to use empiric therapy with a carbapenem.

Carbapenems, including doripenem, imipenem, meropenem, and ertapenem, offer the most reliable coverage for strains containing extended-spectrum β-lactamases. All carbapenems have broad activity against gram-positive cocci, gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes.

Factors that suggest a complicated urinary tract infection:

* Functional or anatomic abnormality of the urinary tract

* Male gender

* Diabetes

* Elderly

* Immunosuppression

* Childhood urinary tract infection

* Recent antimicrobial usage

* Indwelling urinary catheter

* Urinary tract instrumentation

* Hospital-acquired infection

* Symptoms more than 7 days at presentation.

Other options: 

Option B: Amoxiclav is used for the treatment of upper respiratory tract infections and skin and soft tissue infections. Though most cases of UTI are caused by E. coli, due to increased resistance (ESBL-producing strains), it can be challenging to treat with oral beta-lactams and generally, they have lower cure rates compared to other classes of drugs, such as fluoroquinolones or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Option C: Ceftriaxone is given for uncomplicated infections. Fourth and fifth-generation cephalosporins can be used for complicated UTIs.

Option D: Nitrofurantoin is used for the treatment of uncomplicated infections. It is rapidly excreted in the urine but does not obtain therapeutic levels in most body tissues, including the gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, it is not useful for upper tract, complicated infections, or blood-borne infections.

questions.text:
20. Which of the following anaemias responds to erythropoietin?

1. Aplastic anaemia  2. Nutritional anaemia  3. Anaemia of chronic kidney disease 4. Anaemia of Myelofibrotic disorder
questions.solution:
Anaemia of chronic kidney disease responds to erythropoietin.

Erythropoietin (EPO) is useful in anaemia of chronic kidney disease and anaemia of inflammation, in which endogenous EPO levels are inappropriately low. The usual dose of EPO is 50–150 U/kg three times a week intravenously in patients with chronic kidney disease. Most of the patients respond, and haemoglobin levels of 10–12 g/dL are usually reached within 4–6 weeks if iron levels are adequate. The EPO dose can be decreased once a target haemoglobin level is achieved.

Serum erythropoietin levels are typically appropriate for the severity of anemia in patients with myelofibrosis. Patients with inappropriately low serum erythropoietin levels (<125 U/L) considering their degree of anemia can benefit from erythropoietin treatment.

Thus, Anaemia of chronic kidney disease and Anaemia of Myelofibrotic disorder can respond to erythropoietin.

Other statements:

Statement 1: Aplastic anaemia requires haematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Statement 2: Nutritional anaemia responds to supplementing the deficient nutrients such as folic acid, iron and vitamin B12.

questions.text: 21. A 40-year-old chronic smoker undergoes spirometry. FEV1/FVC is 0.65, FVC is 62%, and RV/TLC is 141%. Which of the following describes the condition of his lungs?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a chronic smoker with FEV1/FVC is 0.65, FVC 62%, and RV/TLC 141% signifies obstructive lung disease, which will lead to trapping of air with hyperinflation of lungs.

Chronic smoking leads to airway inflammation and destruction, leading to air trapping and progressive hyperinflation. This further leads to increased residual volume, increased total lung capacity and an increased ratio of residual volume to total lung capacity. To preserve maximum expiratory airflow, hyperinflation of the thorax serves an important role by increasing lung volume and thereby decreasing airway resistance.

At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1). In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced, where the decrease in FEV1 is greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases. 

Other options:

Option B: Restrictive Lung Disease is characterised by a normal to increased FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced residual and lung volumes.

Option C: It is obstructive lung disease and not a normal physiological change with age.

Option D: Compliance refers to the change in lung volume per unit change in surrounding pressure. Compliance can increase in obstructive disease, such as emphysema.

questions.text: 22. A 26-year-old male comes with pus in the urethral meatus and dysuria. He has a history of unprotected heterosexual activity 1 week back. Urinalysis shows plenty of pus cells, and culture for antimicrobial sensitivity shows resistance to penicillins. Gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci, which are mostly intracellular. Which will be the most appropriate management for him?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for him is Ceftriaxone.

The given clinical scenario of a male with a history of unprotected heterosexual activity, dysuria, urinalysis showing plenty of pus cells and gram stain showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Gonococcal urethritis, which is resistant to penicillins. 

Urethral discharge can be classified as gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, or nongonococcal urethritis, caused usually by Chlamydia trachomatis. Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted disease where infection occurs due to the adhesion of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces with the help of pili. By the third day of infection, the cocci have penetrated intracellular spaces and reached subepithelial tissue. The incubation period ranges from 2 to 8 days. The main symptoms are urethral discharge and dysuria.

In males, the disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection has the potential to spread down the urethra and into the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis. Chronic urethritis can lead to stricture formation. Infections in the periurethral tissues can lead to abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses known as watercan perineum.

In females, the infection begins in the cervix and urethra and may spread to the Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. The vaginal mucosa is usually unaffected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to cocci infection and also because vaginal secretions have an acidic pH. Rarely, peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation known as Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain, which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

The image below shows the Gram stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular Gram-negative diplococci.



Pearl PM2456: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

* It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.

* The ulcers are painful.



 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

* It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.

* The ulcers are usually painless.

* Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 

* Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:



 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

* Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.

* The ulcer is painful.

* Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.

* It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 

* Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance



 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

* It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.

* The ulcer is painless.

* Causes painless lymphadenopathy.

* Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.



 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

* It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.

* The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.

* Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:





 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

* It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.

* It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.

* The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.
